(2) Columbus Circle, w.59th Street, Broadway and Eighth Avenue, showing where these avenues meet, at the south western corner of Central Park. The statue of Columbus was erected by the Italians resident in America, and presented on the 12th of October, 1892, the fourth centenary of the discovery of America. Copy right 1893. J.S. Johnston and Co. Photographers, New York City.

title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle.

text:
Central Park: Southwestern entrance (originally called Merchant's Gate), at Columbus Circle, with the ball ground and Green in the center background. The monument at the entrance of the Park was erected to commemorate the sailors who were lost when the battleship Maine was blown up -- the incident which led to the Spanish-American War. The Columbus statue, by Russo, stands on the tall pedestal in the middle of the Circle, in the left foreground. Along the horizon may be seen the buildings on Fifth Avenue and the East Side.

About 1922.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Central Park entrance at Columbus Circle.

text:
(1)
Central Park: Pathway near the Mall; the view is southwest. The tall building on the horizon is the Gotham National Bank Building, which will later come into the possession of The Manufacturers' Trust Company; it is located on 59th Street just west of Columbus Circle.

P. L. Sperr.

(2 & 3)
Two additional views eastward in the same locality to show a Fifth Ave. apartment house through the trees.

1923.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Pathways [near the Mall].

title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle - [Between 58th and 59th Streets (West).]

text:
COLUMBUS CIRCLE, WHERE BROADWAY CROSSES EIGHTH AVE. AT FIFTY-NINTH
ST.
The upper part of Manhattan was laid out more than a hundred years ago upon the gridiron plan. Avenues run north and south and streets run east and west with mathematical and geometrical precision. Practically the only variation from that scheme - north of the "downtown" section - is Broadway, the old post road to Albany, whose slant the city planners found it impossible to change. Broadway intersects at a sharp angle most of the other thoroughfares, thus affording the only vistas in the entire borough and creating what are known as Union Square, Madison Square, Greeley or Herald Square, and Times Square. The picture above shows Broadway at the left and Central Park west, with the Maine
Memorial at the entrance to the park.
1924
Kadel and Herbert
title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle - [Broadway - 8th Avenue - 59th Street.]

text:
Columbus Circle, south side, west from and including Broadway, to, but not including Eighth Ave. The view also shows Broadway, east side, north from but not including West 55th to West 59th Streets, and also Eighth Ave, east side, north from but not including West 56th Street, to and including Columbus Circle.

About 1924.
Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle - Broadway - 8th Avenue.

text:
Columbus Circle, southeast sector, from Central Park South (West 59th Street), across Broadway to Eighth Ave. (right), as viewed southward from a vantage point on Broadway; above West 60th Street. The 20-story structure shown is the United States Rubber Company Building, No. 1784-1790 Broadway, at the S.E. corner of West 58th Street. Note on the right the excavation for the General Motors Building which will occupy the block bounded by Broadway and Eighth Ave., West 57th to 58th Streets.

About 1924.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle - Central Park South - 59th Street (West) - Broadway - 8th Avenue.

text:
An aerial view of Columbus Circle and environs and viewing south-westward from a point over Central Park. About 1928.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle and environs.

text:
Columbus Circle: The eastern half of same, as viewed northeastward from a structure on Eighth Ave. and showing the Christopher Columbus statue; the Maine Monument and Central Park. Note at the foot of the Columbus column, an Army unit; undoubtedly to feed the unemployed.

About 1930.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle - Christopher Columbus statue.

title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle - [Durland's Riding Academy.]

text:
A general view northward from the General Motors Building (Broadway, west to Eighth Ave. and West 57th north to 58th Streets). This view shows Columbus Circle (foreground), Broadway (left), Central Park West (center), and Central Park (right). Construction work for the Eighth Ave. Subway is shown in two places; on the east side of Central Park West and at the foot of the statue of Christopher Columbus in the center of the Circle. Note the Maine Monument at the Park entrance. Across the top of the view (left), appears the Hudson River, with its Palisades (Jersey shore). About 1932.

Brown Brothers.
title: General view - Broadway - 8th Avenue - North.

text:
Central Park: The Southwestern Entrance, originally known as the Merchants' Gate, at Columbus Circle, showing the monument erected to the sailors lost in the sinking of the Maine (the incident that precipitated the Spanish-American War).
May 21, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Central Park entrance at Columbus Circle.

text:
Celebrations: Pay Tribute to Columbus. About 1,000 gathered around Columbus Circle October 12, to pay tribute to the Great Navigator on the 441st Anniversary of his discovery of America. Wreaths were placed at the base of the statue, and addressed in tribute to Columbus were made. Mayor O'Brien was one of those to speak. Here is a general view looking into Central Park in Background.

Associated Press Photo

October 12, 1933.
title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle - Celebrations - Tribute to Columbus.

title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle.

text:
Columbus Circle, northeast segment between Central Park West (left) and Central Park South (right), also known as West 59th Street, and showing the Maine Monument (at entrance to Central Park) and the Columbus Statue (mid circle). Across Central Park appears the east side of Fifth Ave., north from 59th Street with the Sherry-Netherland and the Hotel Pierre Towers silhouetted against the sky. Also shown is Central Park South, east from Columbus Circle with its jumble of apartment houses.

1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.
title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle - Between Central Park West and Central Park South - [59th Street (West).]

Columbus Circle: A set of 2 views forming a panoramic arrangement of the easterly half of these arterial crossroads as viewed eastward. To the left is Central Park; through the center, Central Park South (W. 59th St.), and to the right are buildings extending to Eighth Ave. Broadway, running on a tangent, separates the last two thoroughfares. Upon the site there shown with rodeo billboards, a modern twin apartment building is being completed in March of 1940. This is the old Ehret (Brewing) Estate property.

October 5, 1939
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr
title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle - Easterly half.
